awd_titl_txt: EAGER: The Presence of a Clumped Isotope Signal in Atmospheric Carbon Monoxide (CO)
awd_abstract_narration:
This EAGER project is a high risk, high reward project to measure an isotope of carbon monoxide never before measured in the atmosphere.  It is theorized that this particular isotopic anomaly may be used as a tracer to assess the chemical reactivity of the atmosphere.  Chemical reactivity in the atmosphere differs depending on the season, the amount of sunlight, and other factors. 

This project will measure, for the first time, the 'doubly substituted' isotopologue of atmospheric carbon monoxide 13C18O (31CO).  The study will quantify the 31CO signal in atmospheric CO during different seasons, corresponding to different hydroxyl radical (OH) abundances, by collecting air samples from a mid-latitude, coastal site along the east coast of North America.  Laboratory studies will also be conducted to determine the temperature dependence of 13C18O abundance.  This project may find application in paleoatmospheric studies, as a parallel goal of the project is the evaluation of whether this signal is conserved in Holocene and Pleistocene-age polar ice.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Thie EAGER was to support a novel measurement of a potentially unique and useful trace gas: the double substituted isotopologue of atmospheric carbon monoxide, 13C18O. The abundance of this species, compared to the abundance of atmospheric CO, is about 0.002%. Because of the unusual inverse mass dependent behavior of another isopologue, C18O, and the mass independent fractionation of yet a third isotopologue, C17O, we hypothesized that the double substituted isotopic species 13C18O would also exhibit unusual behavior. We furthermore predicted that this unusual behavior would be similar to that seen for C18O during the atmospheric oxidation reaction C18O+OH. 

We thus developed a method to collect and analyze air samples for 13C18O abundance. Because of the very small amounts of this isotopologue, we needed to cllect large amounts of air and process it. Each sample analyzed required several days' worth of continuous air sample collection and processing via a custom vacuum cryogenic extraction line. The end result was that we succeeded in quantifying this rare species in ambient air, and the behavior was in the same direction as predicted. In fact, 13C18O reacts preferentially with OH radical, which is the oppotsie of normal mass dependent behavior. This is the first time the species has been measured.

The interest of this measurement is twofold. First of all, as a conserved tracer, the magnitude of 13C18O in the atmosphere provides information as to the extent of oxidation that ambient CO has undergone. In other words the 13C18O measurement alone will indicated how much OH there must have been to give the observed signal. THis also means we can go back in time, potentially many thousands of years, by examining air for 13C18O trapped in prehistoric ice.

Secondly, while predicted by us as a result of previous observations of other systems, the behavior of this isotopic system is not well explained by classic kinetic theory and exposes a gap in our understanding of molecular processes, and thus of very fundamental energetics. Many papers have been written about the CO+OH reaction because of its unusual behavior; our observations further emphasize the odd behavior of the various isotope species of atmospheric CO.

We can declare a success with regards to our stated objectives for this EAGER. We exceeded our expectations with both the analytical development and real world observations. This novel work is being submitted for publication in a peer reviewed journal.
